question: Question_B_05_(a)
statement:
Consider the matrix below:

\[A=
\begin{bmatrix}
3  &  1  &  -3\\
-1  &  0  &  2\\
1  &  0  &  0
\end{bmatrix}\].

It is known that $\lambda_1=1$ is an eigenvalue of A.

Find an eigenvector associated with the eigenvalue $\lambda_1 = 1$.
sols:
We want to solve something of the form

\begin{align*}
A\mathbf{x}&=\lambda\mathbf{x}
(A-\lambda{}I)\mathbf{x}&=\mathbf{0}
\end{align*}

where I is the identity matrix. In this case we have $\lambda_1=1$ so we
have that

\[A-\lambda_1I=A-I=
\begin{bmatrix}
2  &  1  &  -3\\
-1  &  -1  &  2\\
1  &  0  &  -1
\end{bmatrix}\].

To solve (A-I)\textbf{x} we write \textbf{x}={[}a,b,c{]} and solve

\[\begin{bmatrix}
2  &  1  &  -3\\
-1  &  -1  &  2\\
1  &  0  &  -1
\end{bmatrix}
\begin{bmatrix}
a\\
b\\
c
\end{bmatrix}
=
\begin{bmatrix}
0\\
0\\
0
\end{bmatrix}\]

which is equivalent to solving

\begin{align*}
2a+b-3c&=0,\\
-a-b+2c&=0,\\
a-c&=0.
\end{align*}

This has solution \emph{b=c=a} for any arbitrary \emph{a}. Therefore we
take \emph{a=1}, without loss of generality, and our eigenvetor is

\[\mathbf{x}=
\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
1\\
1
\end{bmatrix}\].

How do we solve

\[A\mathbf{x}=\lambda\mathbf{x}\]

for \textbf{x} with a given $\lambda$?
